title: 109_s1082
content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia Personal Protection Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that the Second Amendment protects the rights of individuals to keep and bear arms, including law-abiding citizens in the District of Columbia who are deprived of firearms due to local laws. The high murder rate in the District may be linked to these restrictions. The Federal Gun Control Act of 1968, amended by the Firearms Owners' Protection Act of 1986 and the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act of 1993, provides comprehensive regulations in the District of Columbia. Legislation is needed to restore the Second Amendment rights of law-abiding citizens in the District. Legislation is needed to restore Second Amendment rights in the District of Columbia to enhance public safety. Legislation is needed to reform the D.C. Council's authority to restrict firearms in order to restore Second Amendment rights and enhance public safety. The Act prohibits restrictions on firearms possession in the District of Columbia, ensuring individuals can acquire, possess, and use firearms for lawful purposes without undue burden. The District is not authorized to enact laws discouraging private firearm ownership. SEC. 4. REPEAL D.C. SEMIAUTOMATIC BAN. The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to redefine a machine gun as a firearm that can shoot automatically with a single trigger pull. Additionally, criminal penalties related to this definition are also amended. The definition of a machine gun in the Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to align with section 22-4501(c) of the D.C. Official Code. SEC. 5. REPEAL REGISTRATION REQUIREMENT. Repeal of Requirement: Section 201(a) of the Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to only prohibit firearms described in subsection (c), which includes sawed-off shotguns, machine guns, and short-barreled rifles. The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended by repealing sections 202 through 211 and making amendments to sections 101 and 401 regarding firearm possession. Hand loading, reloading, or custom loading of ammunition is allowed for firearms lawfully possessed under this Act. The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to update registration requirements for firearms. Section 402 is amended to clarify eligibility for firearm possession. The Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 is amended to update registration requirements for firearms, including changing "registration certificate" to "dealer's license" in Section 403(b) and making various amendments to Section 404(a)(3) of the D.C. Official Code. Section 406(c) of the Firearms Control Regulations Act is amended to require licensees to remove destructive devices from inventory within 45 days of an unfavorable decision and dispose of firearms and ammunition lawfully. Section 407(b) is amended to prohibit individuals from possessing or receiving firearms if prohibited under Federal or District law. Section 502 is amended to allow the sale or transfer of firearms and ammunition by licensed dealers to individuals not prohibited from possessing them under Federal or District law. Section 407(b) prohibits individuals from possessing or receiving firearms if prohibited under Federal or District law. Section 502 allows the sale or transfer of firearms and ammunition by licensed dealers to individuals not prohibited from possessing them under Federal or District law. Section 704 is amended to remove certain registration certificate requirements. Other conforming amendments are made to the Illegal Firearm Sale and Distribution Strict Liability Act of 1992. SEC. 6. REPEAL HANDGUN AMMUNITION BAN. Definition of Restricted Pistol Bullet amended to include projectiles made from specific materials or larger full-jacketed projectiles for handguns. The definition of a restricted pistol bullet has been amended to exclude certain types of projectiles, such as shotgun shot for hunting, frangible projectiles for target shooting, and projectiles intended for sporting or industrial purposes. Additionally, a ban on ammunition in the Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 has been repealed and replaced with restrictions on pistol bullets. The definition of a restricted pistol bullet has been amended to exclude certain types of projectiles, such as shotgun shot for hunting, frangible projectiles for target shooting, and projectiles intended for sporting or industrial purposes. Additionally, there have been changes in the Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975 regarding restrictions on pistol bullets. SEC. 7. Repeals Section 702 of the Firearms Control Regulations Act of 1975. SEC. 8. Amends Section 706 to remove criminal penalties for possession of unregistered firearms. Effective after 60 days from enactment. SEC. 9. Removes criminal penalties for carrying a firearm in one's dwelling or premises. Section 4(a) of the Act of July 8, 1932 is amended to allow possession of a firearm in one's dwelling, place of business, or on possessed land. Section 5(a) is also amended to replace "pistol" with "firearm" and remove criminal penalties for carrying or transporting. The amendment allows possession and transportation of firearms for various activities without criminal penalties, effective for violations after a 60-day period. The Act allows possession and transportation of firearms without criminal penalties for violations occurring after a 60-day period from the date of enactment.
